history.content:
All these firms suck. Albertsons ftw any day



The type of SWE that’s generally best is the type of SWE that you’re proud of…. It’s subjective and it’s really up to you. Try not to fall into the rat race trap of external validation.
All these firms suck. Albertsons ftw any day

children.subject: thanks for your contribution anon calc! :) added a lot to this post

I hope I'm not misunderstanding you, but I'm taking this as sarcasm.

Why would I contribute to this post if I'm the one who asked the question.
Thanks for your unhelpful answer anon comp :) maybe don't answer at all next time! lol

Have you worked at Amazon before? As someone who has, I can say that the WLB at Amazon is not as bad as it is reputed to be. It really depends on the team and manager. When I interned, I did not notice anyone working excessive hours.
amazon wlb goated, i work max 5 hours a day

Heard the same gear, but I think on average and compared to the rest of the firms in faang it has that reputation, especially if you want to get promoted I heard 50 hours/week is the norm. Also the whole thing about how amazon doesn't really care about it's employees, it prioritizes the customers + products. Take what I say with a grain of salt, this is just what I've heard.

That’s also what I’ve heard from reddit, blind, and other anonymous platforms. But from personal experience (working with full time employees and other interns), I thought that the workload was manageable.  It is true that some people work 50 hours a week, especially if they are looking for a promotion (for instance, my mentor was trying to get promoted from SDE II to SDE III, which is why I saw her putting in extra hours). However, I also saw senior SDEs clocking in at 10 and clocking out at 5. It really depends on how much work you want to put in personally. I had a great experience working at Amazon (good enough to defend it on Piazza lol), so I definitely encourage people to not judge just based on what they’ve heard on anonymous platforms.
FWIW, most people on blind complaining about amazon are low performers. Amazon's PIP is only about 5%, and blind has a skewed concentration of people who are on PIP or close to PIP.

Realistically FAANG is still the gold standard for WLB and pay. If you're super interested in a specific area of SWE, you might find more opportunities for career development/working on interesting projects at a unicorn or quant firm. Note that quant firms/startups can pay more the FAANG, but are usually worse on WLB (with some exceptions like Amazon). Also, quant usually has a pretty high bar for hiring in terms if mathematical skills (ie people who scored well on the Putnam).

I’ll strong disagree with you about the question being unhelpful, but if you deem the question unhelpful then don’t answer, it’s that simple. Sherry answered this question just fine. You also gave your opinion on the question which is still good, it’s all about starting dialogue .. this is the second time I got an albertons student answer and it’s just dumb. Ive had conversations like this with many people and they give insightful answers, so I was trying to get a wider eecs student perspective, but i noticed when jt comes to pay and companies and stuff people get weird lol and I get it but its just frustrating sometimes

"if you deem the question unhelpful then don’t answer, it’s that simple"- Can't say I agree

I like coming to the EECS piazza for the good vibes and interesting posts so I think it is good to politely call out unhelpful stuff to preserve said good vibes. 

Also if you have noticed that people get weird when it comes to money and if you get the meme albertsons answers multiple times, it could be possible that these things are related.

If you want an actual answer to your question look into swe-related subreddits and blind. Both platforms do a great job of providing life advice from like-minded individuals to people like you and me.

Well, don't give an unhelpful response because you are only adding to the unhelpfulness

Ok you might like to come for good vibes, other people like me might be more serious about the EECS piazza and want career advice and there is nothing wrong with that. Why are you policing the eecs piazza lol

It's more like people don't want to share advice on how to be financially successful and happy lol maybe I'm being too harsh 

I did look at those already, but I don't think there is anything wrong with me asking this question on piazza.

But I respect your opinion, no hard feelings.
Look at Alex's response, that is an example of how you could be helpful when answering a question .. people are marking the answer as helpful so Im pretty sure me asking the question is not a waste
You're being too harsh Calc. Lots of good answers here!
? I was just saying an example of someone giving a helpful answer to my 'unhelpful' question I don't get your point poet
I wanted to express pretty much exactly this sentiment but didn’t want to make the effort of typing out a whole paragraph. Ty Karthik

Sure the Albertsons answer is unhelpful but the question posed is also pretty unhelpful. 

The parameters you listed (interesting work, learn a lot, good career development (longevity), good WLB and pay) are things everyone is generally looking for. I think you would be hard-pressed to find someone who didn't want all these things.

The actual question is how much you value each of these factors and what the trade-off point is for you. Would you work 10 hours a day for 50k more per year? Could you work at a place that doesn't really "advance" your career for 100k more per year?

Also based on the companies listed it seems that pay and prestige might be your primary factors? If a company had everything else above but it paid 90k a year and no one really knew about it, would you take it? Nothing wrong with prestige and pay being primary factors, heck I like those two myself, but its worth being honest with yourself about your priorities.

imho unicorns are the best option for young recent grads with lots of energy and willingness to work long hours.

both in terms of building wealth and learning. you'll be granted (often) more stock than you would at a public company/FAANG and those shares will appreciate ludicrously when the unicorn goes public. for learning, the unicorn will often have you be a wearer of many hats and ask you to accept more responsibility than you would at a larger company, especially FAANG. asking you to do more things forces you to learn them, and often you'll get to work with talented people on your team who have already done those things.

just my 2c. but if you're interested in doing something *interesting*, then finance is probably not the industry for you.
This Piazza really does have its moments sometimes lol
albertsons
What? You’re making a lot of assumptions haha I know my priorities and i’m just aggregating information dummy you just hating at this point but it doesn’t matter, I got the info i was looking for

you should determine your own priorities before choosing a company, not the other way round where you have random people give you a pool of companies for you to choose from. You don't ask about any specific factors so of course you're gonna get clowned on for being a clout chasing dweeb

Keep your advice, I’ll be just fine. News flash:  Piazza threads don’t actually translate to real life buddy. If it turns out the way i’m going about it is wrong, i’ll learn the hard way that’s what life is about. But i’m pretty sure asking for direction within the swe industry isn’t going to be harmful to me but to each their own

Here's some advice: you're not going to do well at any of these companies (or elsewhere) if you're not someone other people want to work with. If your reaction to not everyone responding to your post exactly how you want them to is to both be offended and get defensive, you're going to have bigger problems than figuring out what company is the best to work as a SWE at.

Bonus: You asked basically the same question in @16200. Did you ever take the time to self reflect and wonder why you got a joke answer? Furthermore, is it any surprise that if you asked the same ill-defined question twice, you got the same joke answer twice?
Unicorns are private companies (generally startups) that have a valuation of over 1 billion.
What's unicorn? I never heard of that before

To answer your OP, the type of SWE that’s generally best is the type of SWE that you’re proud of.

 It’s subjective and it’s really up to you. Try not to fall into the rat race trap of external validation.

Just my 2 cents

As someone who has worked at
- growing big tech company that manufactures electric cars (non-FAANG but at least 50k employees)
- teenage unicorn company that just went public in December 2021 
- a FAANG company
- first engineer at pre-seed fintech

Learning a lot and interesting work almost always go together. You should set a time for yourself to reflect and figure out what you want to prioritize between WLB, interesting work, pay, “company prestige”.

Others that I personally considered include
- field of work/industry
- work satisfaction(would I love the results on the project/product my team is responsible for?)
- daily work interest(do I genuinely have an interest in the product my team is responsible for)
- project/internal mobility(more applicable to FAANG companies since they’re so big)
- personal engineering growth(mentorship from more senior engineers to learn from)
- career growth opportunities
- organizational impact
- global/social impact
- WLB(Perhaps you would also want to spend more time with family/friends instead of working 100 hour weeks during your prime 20s)

Once you have your prioritizations straight, then you would probably have a clearer picture on “what is best for new grad” per your OP. 

Keep in mind, anywhere you go, you’ll have to learn a lot. Being able to learn a lot is part of the SWE game. So you may need to clarify your personal definition of “learn a lot”(do you want to learn about internal proprietary tools at FAANG that is completely useless outside of that company or do you want to use whatever is the hottest tech/tool?) 

Personally, chasing a company because of how difficult the interviews are and pay seems like a quick way to burnout. SWE is much more than being able to solve Hard problems in leetcode. It’s more about creating value to the world in a scaleable way that’s simply not replicable in other scientific fields.

I'd like to attempt a serious answer to your question. Here we go:

There are a couple of important factors working in SWE. I would say the golden four are:

- Compensation
- Promo speed
- Work/ life balance
- Risk

There are also a couple more "categories" of firms you can work at in SWE. You've got a solid three, but a better list would be

1. FAANG (Facebook and Google mainly)
2. Post-IPO "big N" (Snap, Lyft, Uber, Robinhood, etc.)
3. Established unicorn (Stripe, Databricks, Nuro, etc.)
4. Young unicorn (Brex, Anduril, Figma)
5. Quant (JS, HRT, CitSec, etc.)

Keep in mind there is more out there than this. Startups that just got seed funding. SWE in fields outside of tech. Et cetera et cetera. These are just the most popular and generally top paying categories.

Now let's talk about each category of firm with respect to the golden four factors.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Compensation:

Quant firms lead the pack in new grad pay. (300k-500k)
Big N and established unicorns generally come in next. (200k-270k)

Young unicorns and FAANG generally round out the bottom. (160k-220k)

HOWEVER - new grad pay is a terrible, terrible signal for how strong compensation really is. There's lots of interesting nuanced things - for example, Uber pays <200k to their new grads, but a promotion to L4 commonly happens in 6 months, and pay at L4 at Uber is marked around 280k. I'll touch a little more on this in the promo speed section.

Quant firms will give you the best compensation all around. All the money is cash. There's no money in the form of RSU's like there is in tech, and it's generally about twice as much as tech. 

Big N companies at the top of the pay band (Asana, Lyft, etc.) give you the about the best compensation in tech. 

Established unicorns vary wildly in pay: Nuro and Stripe can go up to 260k+ total compensation, other smaller established unicorns may barely touch 200k. However, a large portion of that money is not liquid, coming in the form of options or RSUs. Generally, when a unicorn is established, it rarely fails, and you can expect that somewhere down the line, whenever a liquidity event happens, your paper RSUs/options will turn into some real money, and ideally net you some good return.

Young unicorns work the same way, except that money in RSUs/options .. could actually turn into paper in the future. Also, you may need to stick it out working at that company to realize those options. (There are more complicated rules about this, depending on the company's clawback policy, but generally you lose options if you leave before the company IPO's but you can keep RSUs.) However!! I've talked about the cons, but the pros could outweigh them: to give you an example, someone who joined Roblox in March 2017 being compensated an average $65,000 in equity per year would see that turn into over 21 million dollars on the IPO date in March 2021. This beats out any of the options discussed above by FAR. But it's all about your risk palate, which I'll address in the risk category. 

FAANG gives you pay that's fantastic, and while it may not reach the top of the top, FAANG is FAANG for a reason. The stock growth you see at a FAANG firm is generally very good and will add some more to the sticker pay.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Promo speed:

Why does promo speed matter, actually? Let's do an example:

I'm going to compare company A and company B.

Company A stats, on average:

L3 -> L4 promo: 1 year
L4 -> L5 promo: 2 years

L3 pay: 170k
L4 pay: 300k
L5 pay: 415k

Company B stats, on average:

L3 -> L4 promo: 2 years
L4 -> L5 promo: 3 years

L3 pay: 200k
L4 pay: 275k
L5 pay: 365k

Over 5 years, an average software engineer who is promoted internally at company A will make (1 * 170) + (2 * 300) + (2 * 415) = $1.6M.

Over 5 years, an average software engineer who is promoted internally at company B will make (2 * 200) + (3 * 275) = $1.2M. 

That's a $400,000 difference, and if you were initially misled by Company A's relatively low new grad pay and not considered promo speed, you could have missed out on a lot of money.

Brownie points if you can figure out what company A and B are.

Now that we know why promo speed is important:

I don't know much about promo at quant firms. Someone else can speak on that.

Facebook and some Big N tech firms generally have the fastest promo speed. Facebook, rideshare, and a select other few firms are notorious for getting engineers to L5 (senior engineer) within 3 years. 

Unicorns vary wildly in terms of average promo speed. Situationally, if a unicorn is in hyper growth, you will have more opportunity to take ownership and get promoted. But it again varies a lot, and if you hit senior in 1.5 years, there's no telling if externally your level will be taken seriously. And if you applied somewhere else, you could be down-leveled. Who knows really. 

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Work-life balance:

Quant firms, with the exception of possibly HRT and JS, have terrible terrible work-life balance. As in, work becomes your life. There are plenty of horror stories of one engineer being assigned a system to build that would take a team of engineers at FAANG six months to build. And they're given two months to do it. 

FAANG and Big N companies generally have the best work-life balance. If you're really gunning hard for promo, it could deteriorate a little, but not unreasonably.

Unicorns in the earlier stages are known to have poor work-life balance, just because there's so much to do, so much that could be breaking, systems are being built with an MVP mindset and not a scalable mindset, etc. etc. Late-stage unicorns generally have a better work-life balance, but not thaaat much better.

Take work/ life balance seriously. What's the use of having so much money if you're not enjoying your prime years and instead staring at a laptop for 10 hours a day? Seriously, take it seriously. 

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Risk:

I want to define risk as both job security and earning potential related. 

In general, again besides maybe HRT and JS, quant firms do not have the greatest job security in software. Software engineers are relatively replaceable in the quant space, whereas traders and researchers are preserved because they are very hard to come by. 

Job security everywhere else is fine (I think).

In terms of earning potential, there's a lot of risk involved with joining an earlier stage unicorn. If your equity goes to zero, that's a lot of money lost. But there's also 10x potential. 

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Conclusion:

I want to talk a little about the path that I think I'm taking post grad. Weighing all of these factors, I'm likely joining a Big N company with top of band tech compensation, quick promo speed, and good work-life balance. Personally, I have a low appetite for risk, as I don't have much starting capital, and don't have anything to fall back on if I join an earlier stage unicorn and it fails. However, I think after hitting senior level at this Big N company, my outlook on risk would become a lot more positive, as I now have some money in the bank and would have fallbacks in place if my stint at a unicorn didn't work out. So after this 3-4 year stint, I think I'd join a Series B ish startup. IDK. This is way in the future, and super subject to change.

This is just my decision based on my risk palate, how much I value compensation and work-life balance, and also my talent limitation (I don't think I can clear the bar to join an earlier stage unicorn company or a quant firm). Based on all of these factors, you can come up with your own path post-grad.

As a final note: this writeup I've done centers very heavily on compensation. We call this a shrigma mindset. If you shrigma too hard, you can lose sight of many important things in life. Make sure you actually LIKE the work you're doing at whatever firm. Make sure you don't have some moral dissonance against working at wherever you're working. Again, make sure you have time to live life. Work is work, and while it's very important for your future, it needs to be compartmentalized into just one pocket of your life. 

A final final note: we talk about this kind of thing all the time in the #career channel of https://discord.gg/eecs. I would recommend you to join and talk to us there. You'd also get a lot of other perspectives on this.

history.content:
What is the best for a new grad wanting to do interesting work, learn a lot, good career development (longevity), good WLB and pay? At this point I only considered FAANG, but I'm hearing about Quant firms and unicorns as having a higher hiring bar + better pay so Im wondering if they are better options than FAANG. Thanks.

Thoughts on

SWE at a

  • Quant firm e.g. Jane Street
  • Unicorn e.g. Stripe, Nuro etc.
  • FAANG e.g. Google/Facebook
history.subject: What type of swe is generally the best?
